{{redirect|Dismember}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} [[Image:Dieric Bouts 013.jpg|thumb|200px|The ''Martyrdom of [[Hippolytus of Rome|St. Hippolytus]]'' by [[Dieric Bouts]]]] [[File:Coyolxauhqui 4095977415 b89d64f008-2.jpg|200px|thumb|[[Aztec]] [[Templo Mayor|stone disk]] depicting a dismembered [[Coyolxauhqui]] which was found during construction in 1978 in [[Mexico City]]. Its discovery led to the excavation of the [[Templo Mayor]].]] '''Dismemberment''' is the act of cutting, tearing, pulling, wrenching or otherwise removing the limbs of a living thing. It has been practised upon human beings as a form of capital punishment, especially in connection with [[regicide]], but can occur as a result of a traumatic accident, or in connection with murder, suicide, or cannibalism. As opposed to [[surgical]] [[amputation]] of the limbs, dismemberment is often fatal to all but the simplest of creatures. In [[criminology]], a distinction is made between offensive and defensive dismemberment. Intentional, criminal dismemberment is known as ''mayhem''. [[File:Execution of thomas armstrong 1683.jpg|thumb|The execution of Sir Thomas Armstrong, who was hanged, drawn and quartered in England for high treason in 1684]]
==History==
===Cut apart=== ;Sliced to pieces by elephant Particularly in South-Eastern Asia, [[Execution by elephant|execution by trained elephants]] was a form of capital punishment practiced for several centuries. The techniques by which the convicted person was actually executed varied widely but did, on occasion, include the elephant dismembering the victim by means of sharp blades attached to its feet. The Muslim traveller [[Ibn Battuta]], visiting Delhi in the 1330s, has left the following eyewitness account of this particular type of execution by elephants:<ref>Battuta, "[https://books.google.com/books?id=IZ5CAAAAcAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=intitle:The+intitle:travels+intitle:of+intitle:Ibn+intitle:Battuta&hl=no&sa=X&ei=8K36UOuaLImF4gTe4YDoAw&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false The travels of Ibn Battuta]", transl. Lee, S, London 1829, pp. 146–47</ref> {{quote|"Upon a certain day, when I myself was present, some men were brought out who had been accused of having attempted the life of the Vizier. They were ordered, accordingly, to be thrown to the elephants, which had been taught to cut their victims to pieces. Their hoofs were cased with sharp iron instruments, and the extremities of these were like knives. On such occasions the elephant-driver rode upon them: and, when a man was thrown to them, they would wrap the trunk about him and toss him up, then take him with the teeth and throw him between their fore feet upon the breast, and do just as the driver should bid them, and according to the orders of the Emperor. If the order was to cut him to pieces, the elephant would do so with his irons, and then throw the pieces among the assembled multitude: but if the order was to leave him, he would be left lying before the Emperor, until the skin should be taken off, and stuffed with hay, and the flesh given to the dogs."|sign=|source=}} ;Quartering procedure in the Holy Roman Empire [[File:Tiradentes escuartejado (Tiradentes supliciado) by Pedro Américo 1893.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Tiradentes|Tiradentes Quartered]]'', [[Pedro Américo]] (1893)]] In the [[Holy Roman Empire]] emperor [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]]'s 1532 [[Constitutio Criminalis Carolina]] specifies how ''every'' dismemberment (quartering) should ideally occur:<ref>German original "Zu der Viertheylung: Durch seinen gantzen Leib zu vier stücken zu schnitten und zerhawen, und also zum todt gestrafft werden soll, und sollen solche viertheyl auff gemeyne vier wegstrassen offentlich gehangen und gesteckt werden"</ref>{{quote|"Concerning quartering: To cut and hack apart his entire body into four pieces, and thus be punished unto death, and such four parts are to be hanged on stakes publicly on four common thorough-fares."|sign=|source=}} Thus, the imperially approved way to dismember the convict within the Holy Roman Empire was by means of ''cutting'', rather than dismemberment through ''ripping'' the individual apart. In paragraph 124 of the same code, beheading prior to quartering is mentioned as allowable when extenuating circumstances are present, whereas aggravating circumstances may allow pinching/ripping the criminal with glowing pincers, prior to quartering.<ref>{{cite book|last=Koch|first=Johann Christoph|title=Hals- oder peinliche Gerichtsordnung Kaiser Carls V. und des H. Röm. Reichs nach der Originalausgabe vom J. 1533 auf das genaueste abgedruckt und mit der zweiten und dritten Ausgabe v. J. 1533 und 1534 verglichen|publisher=J.C. Krieger|year=1824|location=Marburg|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q_o6AAAAcAAJ&printsec=frontcover&hl=no#v=onepage&q&f=false|pages=91, 60|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>
The fate of [[Wilhelm von Grumbach]] in 1567, a maverick knight in the Holy Roman Empire who was fond of making his own private wars and was thus condemned for treason, is also worthy of note. Gout-ridden, he was carried to the execution site in a chair and bound fast to a table. The executioner then ripped out his heart, and stuck it in von Grumbach's face with the words: "von Grumbach! Behold your false heart!" Afterwards, the executioner quartered von Grumbach's body. His principal associate was given the same treatment, and an eyewitness avers (confirms)<!--Note that this word "avers" is not a mistake; it means "affirms".--> that ''after'' his heart had been ripped out, Chancellor Brück screamed horribly for "quite some time".<ref>{{cite book|last=Ortloff|first=Friedrich|title=Geschichte der Grumbachischen Händel, Volume 4|publisher=Friedrich Frommann|year=1870|location=Jena|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qw9TAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA156|pages=156–158|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>
One example of a highly aggravated execution is illustrated by the fate of Bastian Karnhars on 16 July 1600. Karnhars was found guilty of 52 separate acts of murder, including the rape and murder of 8 women, and the murder of a child, whose heart he had allegedly eaten for rituals of black magic. To begin, Karnhars had three strips of flesh torn from his back, before being pinched 18 times with glowing pincers, having his fingers clipped off one by one, his arms and legs [[broken on the wheel]], and finally, while still alive, quartered.<ref>{{cite book|last=Becherer|first=Johann|title=Neue Thüringische Chronica|publisher=Martin Spiess|year=1601|location=Müllhausen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fds-AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA648|pages=648|accessdate=2013-03-24}} See also the 3-day long torture and execution method of [[Peter Niers]], who was executed in 1581 for 544 murders, including the murder of 24 women and their fetuses, the latter to be used in rituals of black magic.</ref> ;A fabled Turkish execution method In the seventeenth century, a number of travel reports speak of an exotic "Turkish" execution method, where first, the waist of a man was constricted by ropes and cords, and then a swift bisection of the trunk was performed. [[William Lithgow (traveller and author)|William Lithgow]] presents a comparatively prosaic description of the method:<ref>{{cite book|last=Lithgow|first=William|title=The Totall Discourse, of the Rare Aduentures, and Painefull Peregrinations of Long Nineteene Yeares Trauayles from Scotland, to the Most Famous Kingdomes in Europe, Asia, and Affrica|publisher=Nicholas Okes|year=1632|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=41oj3JOOUAwC&pg=PA153|pages=153|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref> {{quote|"If a Turke should happen to kill another Turke (...) he is brought forth to the market place, and a blocke being brought hither of foure foote high; the malefactor is stripd naked; and then layd thereupon with his belly downeward, they drawe in his middle together so small with running cords, that they strike his body a two with one blow: his hinder parts they cast to be eaten by hungry dogges kept for the same purpose; and the forequarters and head they throw into a grievous fire, made there for the same end .-and this is the punishment for man-slaughter."|sign=|source=}} [[George Sandys]], however, during the same period, tells of a method as no longer in use, in a rather more mythologized way:<ref>{{cite book|last=Sandys|first=George|title=A Relation of a Journey Begun an Dom. 1610. Foure Bookes Coutaining a Description of the Turkish Empire, of Aegypt, of the Holy Land, of the Remote Parts of Italt, and Islands Adjoyning|publisher=W. Barren|year=1615|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6jxFnu9A_MYC&pg=PA63|pages=63|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref> {{quote|"...they twitch the offender about the waist with a towell, enforcing him to draw up his breath by often pricking him in the body, until they have drawn him within the compasse of a span; then tying it hard, they cut him off in the middle, and setting the body on a hot plate of copper, which seareth the veines, they so up-propping him during their cruell pleasure: who not only retaineth his sense, but the faculties of discourse, until he be taken downe; and then he departeth in an instant."|sign=|source=}} ;Shekkeh in Persia In 1850s Persia, a particular dismemberment technique called ''shekkeh'' is reported to have been used. Travelling as an official for the [[East India Company]] Robert Binning<ref>[http://www.docs.is.ed.ac.uk/docs/lib-archive/bgallery/Gallery/records/eighteen/binning.html Robert B.M. Binning] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130618214312/http://www.docs.is.ed.ac.uk/docs/lib-archive/bgallery/Gallery/records/eighteen/binning.html |date=18 June 2013 }}</ref> describes it as follows:<ref>{{cite book|last=Binning|first=Robert B.M.|title=A Journal of Two Years' Travel in Persia, Ceylon, Etc, Volume 1|publisher=Wm. H. Allen and Company|year=1857|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WUi9fw-UcnoC&pg=PA274|page=274|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>{{quote|"the criminal is hung up by the heels, head downwards, from a ladder or between two posts, and the executioner hacks away with a sword, until the body is bisected lengthways, terminating at the head. The two several halves are then suspended on a camel, and paraded through the streets, for the edification of all beholders. When the shekkeh is to be inflicted in a merciful manner, the culprit's head is struck off, previous to bisecting the trunk."|sign=|source=}}
;Korea Dismemberment was a form of capital punishment for convicts of [[high treason]] in the Korean kingdom of the [[Joseon Dynasty]]. This punishment was, for example, meted out to Hwang Sa-Yong in 1801.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jai-Keun|first=Choi|pages=135|title=The Origin of the Roman Catholic Church in Korea: An Examination of Popular and Governmental Responses to Catholic Missions in the Late Chosôn Dynasty|publisher=The Hermit Kingdom Press|year=2006|location=Norwalk, California|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sydu4aOL-WoC&pg=PA135|isbn=9781596890640|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref> ;China [[The Five Pains]] is a Chinese variation invented during the [[Qin dynasty]]. During the [[Tang dynasty]] (618-907 CE), [[Waist chop|truncation of the body at the waist]] by means of a fodder knife was a death penalty reserved for those who were seen to have done something particularly treacherous or repugnant.<ref>{{cite book|last=Benn|first=Charles D.|title=China's Golden Age: Everyday Life in the Tang Dynasty|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2002|location=Oxford|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ile3jSveb4sC&pg=PA210|page=210|isbn=9780195176650|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref> That practice of cutting in two did not originate in the Tang dynasty; in sources concerning the [[Han dynasty]] (206 BCE-220 CE), no less than 33 cases of execution by cutting at the waist are mentioned, but occurs very rarely in earlier material.<ref>{{cite book|last=[http://www.zo.uni-heidelberg.de/md/zo/sino/institute/staff/kampen/eacs_scholar_hulsewe.pdf Hulsewé]|first=Anthony François Paulus|title=Remnants of Chʻin Law: An Annotated Translation of the Chʻin Legal and Administrative Rules of the 3rd Century B.C. Discovered in Yün-meng Prefecture, Hu-pei Province, in 1975|publisher=BRILL|year=1985|location=Leyden|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M7oseTr553wC&pg=PA14|page=14|isbn=9789004071032|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>
;Current use Dismemberment is no longer used by most modern governments as a form of execution or [[torture]], though [[amputation#As a punishment in Islam|amputation]] is still carried out in countries that practice [[Sharia law]].<ref>[http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1371270.php/Saudi_Arabia_chops_off_hand_of_Egyptian_for_theft Saudi Arabia chops off hand of Egyptian for theft] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811044139/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1371270.php/Saudi_Arabia_chops_off_hand_of_Egyptian_for_theft |date=11 August 2010 }}, 5 November 2007</ref>
===Torn apart=== Dismemberment was carried out in the [[Middle Ages|Medieval]] and [[Early Modern era]] and could be effected, for example, by tying a person's limbs to chains or other restraints, then attaching the restraints to separate movable entities (e.g. vehicles) and moving them in opposite directions.
====Torn apart by four horses==== Also referred to as "disruption" or being "drawn and quartered", dismemberment could be brought about by chaining four horses to the condemned's arms and legs, thus making them pull him apart, as was the case with the executions of [[François Ravaillac]] in 1610 and [[Robert-François Damiens]] in 1757. Ravaillac's extended torture and execution has been described like this:<ref>{{cite book|last=Tapié|first=Victor L.|title=France in the Age of Louis Xiii and Richelieu|publisher=CUP Archive|year=1984|location=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KPM3AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA62|pages=62–63|isbn=9780521269247|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>{{quote|"He was condemned to be tortured with red-hot pincers on four limbs and on each breast. His wounds were to be sprinkled with molten lead and boiling oil and his body was then to be torn in pieces by four horses, the remains being subsequently burnt."}} In the case of Damiens, he was condemned to essentially the same fate as Ravaillac, but the execution did not quite work according to plan, as the eyewitness [[Giacomo Casanova]] could relate:<ref>Described in {{cite book|last=Thompson|first=Irene|title=The A to Z of Punishment and Torture|publisher=Book Guild Publishing|year=2008|location=Brighton|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TE2KfBWPAt0C&pg=PA103|pages=103–104|isbn=9781846242038|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>{{quote|Damiens' agony went on for hours as each torture was applied. When the horses failed to disconnect the sinews between his body and his limbs, his body, still alive, was quartered with a knife. His friend, the infamous Casanova, reports that he "watched the dreadful sight for four hours." "I was obliged to turn away my face and to stop my ears as I heard his piercing shrieks, half his body having been torn from him."|sign=|source=}} [[Image:Tupac amaru execution.jpg|235px|thumb|The execution of [[Túpac Amaru II]], who was dismembered by four horses 18 May 1781.]] As late as in 1781, this gruesome punishment was meted out to the [[Peruvian people|Peruvian]] rebel leader [[Túpac Amaru II]] by the Spanish colonial authorities. The following is an extract from the official judicial death sentence issued by the Spanish authorities which condemns Túpac Amaru II to torture and death. It was ordered in the sentence that Túpac Amaru II be condemned to have his tongue cut out, after watching the executions of his family, and to have his hands and feet tied... {{quote|...to four horses who will then be driven at once toward the four corners of the plaza, pulling the arms and legs from his body. The torso will then be taken to the hill overlooking the city... where it will be burned in a bonfire... Tupac Amaru's head will be sent to Tinta to be displayed for three days in the place of public execution and then placed upon a pike at the principal entrance to the city. One of his arms will be sent to Tungasuca, where he was the cacique, and the other arm to the capital province of Carabaya, to be similarly displayed in those locations. His legs will be sent to Livitica and Santa Rosas in the provinces of Chumbivilcas and Lampa, respectively."<ref>{{cite book|title=Latin American Independence: An Anthology of Sources|year=2010|publisher=Hackett Publishing Company, Inc.|location=Indianapolis|isbn=9780872208636|pages=36, 37|author=Sarah C. Chambers|author2=John Charles Chasteen}}</ref>|sign=|source=}}
====The fate of Queen Brunhilda==== [[File:Brunhilda.jpg|thumb|100px|left|Execution of Brunhilda, engraving by Paul Girardet after [[Henri Félix Emmanuel Philippoteaux]]]] Queen [[Brunhilda of Austrasia]], executed in 613, is generally regarded to have suffered the same death, though one account has it that she was tied to the tail of a single horse and thus suffered more of a [[dragging death]]. The [[Liber Historiae Francorum]], an eighth century chronicle, describes her death by dismemberment as follows:<ref>Cited in {{cite book|last=Bitel|first=Lisa M.|title=Women in Early Medieval Europe, 400–1100|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2002|location=Cambridge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XRudk_NcA7cC&pg=PA83|pages=83|isbn=9780521597739|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>{{quote|"Then King [[Chlothar II|Chlothar]] ordered that she be lifted onto a camel and led through the entire army. Then she was tied to the feet of wild horses and torn apart limb from limb. Finally, she died."|sign=|source=}} The story of Brunhilda being tied to the tail of a ''single'' horse (and then to die in some gruesome manner) is promoted, for example, by Ted Byfield (2003), in which he writes: "Then they tied her to the tail of a wild horse; whipped into frenzy, it kicked her to death"<ref>{{cite book|last=Byfield|first=Ted|title=Darkness Descends : A.D. 350 to 565, the Fall of the Western Roman Empire|publisher=Christian History Project|year=2003|location=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kZA4wyCSfUAC&pg=PA223|pages=223|isbn=9780968987339|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref> The cited source for this claim, however, the seventh century "Life of St. Columban" by the monk Jonas, does not support this claim. In paragraph 58 in his work, Jonas just writes: "..but Brunhilda he had placed first on a camel in mockery and so exhibited to all her enemies round about then she was bound to the tails of wild horses and thus perished wretchedly"<ref>Internet History Sourcebooks,[http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/basis/columban.asp Medieval Sourcebook: The Life of St. Columban, by the Monk Jonas, (7th Century)], paragraph 58</ref>
The storyline of Brunhilde being tied to the tail of a single horse and being subsequently ''dragged'' to death has become a classical motif in artistic representations, as can be seen by the included image.
====Torn apart by four ships==== According to [[Olfert Dapper]], a 17th-century Dutchman who meticulously collected reports from faraway countries from seamen and other travelers, a fairly frequent maritime death penalty among the corsairs on the Barbary coast was to affix the hands and feet to chains on four different ships. When the ships then sailed off in different directions, the chains grew taut, and the man in between was torn apart after a while.<ref>*{{cite book|last=Dapper|first=Olfert|title=Umbstaendliche und eigentliche Beschreibung von Africa|year=1670|publisher=J. von Meurs|location=Amsterdam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oBs-AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA167|pages=167|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref>
====Torn apart by two trees==== Roman military discipline could be extremely severe, and the emperor [[Aurelian]] (r. 270–275 CE), who had a reputation for extreme strictness, instituted the rule that soldiers who seduced the wives of their hosts should have their legs fastened to two bent-down trees, which were then released, ripping the man in two.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sabin|first1=Philip|last2=van Wees|first2=Hans|last3=Whitby|first3=Michael|title=The Cambridge History of Greek and Roman Warfare: Volume 2, Rome from the Late Republic to the Late Empire|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2007|location=Cambridge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4aX-W6AVNv8C&pg=PA439|pages=439|isbn=9780521782746|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref> Similarly, in an unsuccessful rebellion against the emperor [[Valens]] in 366 CE, the usurper [[Procopius (usurper)|Procopius]] met the same fate.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mariev|first=Sergei|title=Ioannis Antiocheni fragmenta quae supersunt omnia|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|year=2008|location=Berlin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qY065QbJL7MC&pg=PA374|pages=374–375|isbn=9783110210316|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>
After the defeat of [[Darius III]] by [[Alexander the Great]], the Persian monarchy was thrown into turmoil, and Darius was killed. One man, [[Bessus]], claimed the throne as Artaxerxes V, but in 329 BCE, Alexander had him executed. The manner of Bessus' death is rather disputed, and Waldemar Heckel writes:<ref>{{cite book|last=Heckel|first=Waldemar|title=The Conquests of Alexander the Great|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2012|location=Cambridge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Chu5MBz1gbQC&pg=PA95|pages=95|isbn= 9781107645394|accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>{{quote|The exact details of Bessus' death are disputed. He may have been crucified, or torn apart by recoiling trees, or (what is most likely) mutilated before being sent to [[Ecbatana]] for execution.}} The method of tying people to bent down trees, which are then allowed to recoil, ripping the individual to pieces in the process is, however, mentioned by several travelers to nineteenth century Persia. The British diplomat [[James Justinian Morier]] travelled as a special envoy to the Shah in 1808, and Morier writes the following concerning then prevailing criminal justice:<ref>{{cite book|last=Morier|first=James Justinian|title=A Journey Through Persia, Armenia and Asia Minor, to Constantinople, in the Years 1808 and 1809|publisher=Longman Hurst|year=1812|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KM-Tdt38mAoC&pg=PA204|pages=204|isbn= |accessdate=2013-03-24}}</ref>{{quote|..for the King never pardons theft, and orders a convicted thief to be executed instantly. The mode is as follows: two young trees are by main strength brought together at their summits, and there fastened with cords together. The culprit is then brought out, and his legs are tied with ropes, which are again carried up and: fixed to the top of the trees. The cords that force the trees together are then cut; and, in the elasticity and power of this spring, the body of the thief is torn asunder, and left thus to hang divided on each separate tree. The inflexibility of the King in this point has given to the roads a security, which, in former times, was little known.}}
====Torn apart by stones==== An obscure Christian martyr, Severianus<ref>[http://www.heiligenlexikon.de/BiographienS/Secundus_Carpophorus_Victorinus_Severianus.html Secundus, Carpophorus, Victorinus und Severianus]</ref> was, about the year 300 AD, martyred in the following way, according to one tale: One stone was fastened to his head, another bound to his feet. His middle was then fastened by a rope to the top of a wall, and the stones released from the height. His body was ripped apart.<ref>{{cite book|last=Münchhausen|first=Albert F., Freiherr von|title=Die Attribute der Heiligen, alphabetisch geordnet (etc.) Nebst einem Anh.: uber die Kleidung der kath. Welt- und Ordensgeistlichen|publisher=Hahn|year=1843|location=Hannover|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qx9LAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA171|pages=171|isbn= |accessdate=}}</ref>
====A Christian martyr withstands being torn apart==== During the reign of the Roman Emperor [[Diocletian]] a Christian named Shamuna was, allegedly, torn apart in the following manner:{{quote|The governor immediately ordered that Shamuna should be made to kneel down on one side and that an iron chain should be fastened on his knee. This having been done, he hung him up head downwards by the foot with which he had made him kneel; the other he pulled downwards with a heavy piece of iron, which cannot be described in words: thus endeavouring to rend the champion in two. By this means the socket of the hip-bone was wrenched out of its place and Shamuna became lame.}} Some time thereafter, Shamuna was taken down from his hanging position, and was beheaded instead.<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0858.htm Martyrdom of Shamuna, Guria and Habib]</ref>
===Homicide cases=== There are many instances of dismemberment in murder cases. Examples of victims include [[Murder of Bernard Oliver|Bernard Oliver]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/uk-england-suffolk-38527821/tattingstone-suitcase-murder-police-appeal-over-bernard-oliver-death|title=Suitcase murder a mystery 50 years on|website=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> [[Omaima Nelson|Bill Nelson]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Woman who cut up husband seeks parole today |date= 28 September 2001|journal=The Orange County Register|author=Welborn, Larry|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/nelson-319333-omaima-pawloski.html|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> [[William Trickett Smith II|Jana Claudia Gómez Menéndez]],<ref name="Patriot-News-20100826-notoriety">{{cite news|last=DeJesus|first=Ivey|url=http://penn.live.advance.net/news/patriotnews/index.ssf?/base/news/128279310880950.xml&coll=1|title=For area man in Peru prison, more notoriety|newspaper=[[The Patriot-News]]|pages=1–3|accessdate=2010-09-04|date=26 August 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Murder of Jessica Ridgeway|Jessica Ridgeway]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2013/11/19/austin-sigg-sentenced-to-life-in-kidnapmurder-of-jessica-ridgeway/|title=Austin Sigg sentenced to life in kidnap/murder of Jessica Ridgeway|date=19 November 2013|work=The Denver Post|access-date=2018-05-27|language=en-US}}</ref> [[Murder of Becky Watts|Becky Watts]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-34658848|title=Becky accused denies killing 'pleasure'|date=28 October 2015|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-05-12|language=en-GB}}</ref> [[Death of Ingrid Lyne|Ingrid Lyne]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/seattle-nurse-dismembered-home-man-dating-article-1.2598470|title=Seattle nurse dismembered in her home by man she was dating; bail for suspected killer set at $2 million – NY Daily News|last=Salinger|first=Tobias|work=nydailynews.com|access-date=2018-05-12|language=en-US}}</ref> [[Jamal Khashoggi]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/17/world/europe/turkey-saudi-khashoggi-dismember.html|title=Audio Offers Gruesome Details of Jamal Khashoggi Killing, Turkish Official Says|access-date=2018-10-22|language=en}}</ref> and [[Murder of Kim Wall|Kim Wall]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/apr/25/peter-madsen-sentenced-life-murdering-kim-wall-submarine|title=Peter Madsen sentenced to life for murdering journalist Kim Wall|last=Orange|first=Richard|date=25 April 2018|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=25 April 2018}}</ref> Serial killer [[Jeffrey Dahmer]] is also known to have dismembered and cannibalized his victims.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,973550-1,00.html "The Little Flat of Horrors"], ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', 5 August 1991</ref>
==Examples in fiction==
===Anime=== *''[[Baccano!]]'', premiered in 2007 *''[[Dansai Bunri no Crime Edge]]'', premiered on 4 April 2013
===Film=== Dismemberment has been portrayed in many films; although a few are depictions of historical or actual events, a significant number are within the [[Horror film|horror genre]]. Filmmakers can be quite innovative in the methods depicted, and thus reflect the public's fear and fascination with this method of torture, homicide, and/or body disposal. The following movies portray or imply dismemberment in some form; exceptional methods or motives are described. [[Baahubali: The Beginning|Bahubali The Beginning (2015)]] - dismemberment of Bhadra by Mahendra Bahubali [[Baahubali 2: The Conclusion|Bahubali The Conclusion (2017)]] - dismemberment of Sethupati by Amarendra Bahubali * ''[[127 Hours]]'' (2010) – self-dismemberment of hand * ''[[2001 Maniacs]]'' (2005) – dismemberment by horses * ''[[Black Death (film)|Black Death]]'' (2010) – dismemberment by horses * ''[[Bone Tomahawk]]'' (2015) – dismembered * ''[[Boxing Helena]]'' (1993) – women held captive by a surgeon in his home who dismembers her. * ''[[Braindead (film)|Braindead]]'' (1992) * ''[[Braveheart]]'' (1995) – Sir [[William Wallace]] is [[hanged, drawn, and quartered]], then beheaded. * ''[[Bride of Chucky]]'' (1998) – victims dismembered by falling shards of glass * ''[[Cabin Fever 2: Spring Fever]]'' (2009) – self-dismemberment * ''[[Donnie Brasco (film)|Donnie Brasco]]'' (1997) – [[American mafia|mob]] hit victims are dismembered in a basement * ''[[Earth (1998 film)|Earth]]'' (1998) – victim pulled apart between two cars * ''[[Friday the 13th Part III]]'' (1982) - [[Jason Voorhees]] hacks off a victim's hand before killing him * ''[[The Green Inferno (film)|Green Inferno]]'' (2013) – victim gouged and cut apart with axe while alive * ''[[Kill Bill]]'' (2003) * ''[[Kraken: Tentacles of the Deep]]'' (2006) female scuba diver's leg gets ripped off by a giant squid * ''[[Law Abiding Citizen]]'' (2009) – victim paralyzed with toxin and provided with mirror before live dismemberment * ''[[Monty Python and the Holy Grail]]'' (1975) – during a sword fight, the victim has each of his limbs severed one by one, all the while taunting his opponent and refusing to back down. * ''[[Pathfinder (2007 film)|Pathfinder]]'' (2007) * ''[[Pieces (film)|Pieces]]'' (1982) – about the hunt for a serial killer who uses his victims to create a human [[jigsaw puzzle]] of his deceased [[mother]]. * ''[[Saw (2004 film)|Saw]]'' (2004) – self-dismemberment of foot * ''[[Saw IV]]'' (2007) – dismemberment by automated machine * ''[[Scarface (1983 film)|Scarface]]'' (1983) – dismemberment of arms by chainsaw * ''[[Shaun of the Dead]]'' (2004) – [[disembowelment]] followed by dismemberment by [[zombie]]s * ''[[Sin City (film)|Sin City]]'' (2005) * ''[[The Hitcher (1986 film)|The Hitcher]]'' (1986) and ''[[The Hitcher (2007 film)|The Hitcher]]'' (2007) – victim chained between a [[semi-trailer truck|truck and trailer]] and pulled apart * ''[[The Lost World: Jurassic Park]]'' (1997) – Eddie Carr ([[Richard Schiff]]) is dismembered from the waist by two tyrannosaurus rexes before being devoured * ''[[The Paleface (1948 film)|The Paleface]]'' (1948) – attempted execution by tying the victim's feet to two bent-down trees, then using the trees to rip him apart * ''[[The Texas Chain Saw Massacre]]'' (1974) * ''[[The Thaw (2009 film)|The Thaw]]'' (2009) – self-dismemberment * ''[[Twilight (2008 film)|Twilight]]'' (2008) – decapitation followed by dismemberment * ''[[Wagons East!]]'' (1994) – dismembered by horses
===Folklore=== *In [[Aztec mythology]], the god [[Huitzilopochtli]] dismembers his sister [[Coyolxauhqui]] for trying to kill their mother, [[Coatlicue]]; he tossed his sister's head into the sky, where it became the moon *In [[Egyptian mythology]], the demon [[Set (mythology)|Set]] dismembers his brother [[Osiris]] so he could not be resurrected *In [[Greek mythology]], the god [[Dionysus]] is dismembered by the [[Titan (mythology)|Titan]]s, and [[Orpheus]], according to [[Ovid]], is dismembered by [[Ciconian]] women. *In [[Japanese mythology]], [[Izanagi]] dismembers [[Kagutsuchi]] in revenge for the death of his lover [[Izanami]]
===Literature=== *In ''[[The Divine Comedy]]'', falsifiers are dismembered, only to be healed and have the process start over again *In ''[[The Lovely Bones]]'', a 14-year-old girl is murdered and dismembered. *In the "[[Tell-Tale Heart]]" the unnamed victim is murdered, dismembered and hid under the floorboards of his own house.
===Television=== *Multiple episodes of ''[[The Sopranos]]'' discussed or showed mafiosi dismembering bodies; for example, in "[[Whoever Did This]]", [[Tony Soprano]] and [[Christopher Moltisanti]] dismember and decapitate the body of [[Ralph Cifaretto]]. *The television series ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]'' showed many dismemberments by both protagonists and antagonists alike. For example, in the first two episodes of the [[24 (season 2)|second season]], [[Jack Bauer]] decapitates a federal witness to get back undercover with a terrorist group that can lead authorities to a stolen [[nuclear weapon]]. *In [[Spartacus: War of the Damned]], a man captured in battle is dismembered by a group of soldiers. *In [[Moon Embracing the Sun]], a [[Shaman]] is dismembered because of being accused of a crime. *In the Joseon-era Korean drama ''[[Maids (2015 TV series)|Maids]]'', Guk In-yeob is made to watch her father be dismembered after he is accused of treason. *In the Netflix original show ''[[Narcos]]'', Pacho publicly draws and quarters Salazar via motorcycle *Happens in nearly every episode of ''[[Superjail!]]''

The '''disposable soma theory of aging''' states that organisms age due to an evolutionary trade-off between growth, reproduction, and [[DNA repair|DNA repair maintenance]].<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal |authors=Kirkwood, T. | year = 1977 | title = Evolution of ageing | journal = Nature | volume = 270 | issue = | pages = 301–304 | doi=10.1038/270301a0| bibcode = 1977Natur.270..301K }}</ref> Formulated by [[Thomas Kirkwood]], the disposable soma theory explains that an organism only has a limited amount of resources or "soma" that it can allocate to its various [[cellular processes]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Gavrilov LA, Gavrilova NS | year = 2002 | title = Evolutionary theories of aging and longevity | journal = ScientificWorldJournal | volume = 7 | issue =2 | pages = 339–356 | doi=10.1100/tsw.2002.96}}</ref> Therefore, a greater investment in growth and reproduction would result in reduced investment in DNA repair maintenance, leading to increased [[Cell damage|cellular damage]], [[telomere#shortening|shortened telomeres]], accumulation of [[mutation#harmful mutations|mutations]], compromised [[stem cells]], and ultimately, [[senescence]]. Although many models, both animal and human, have appeared to support this theory, parts of it are still controversial. Specifically, while the [[evolutionary trade-off]] between [[Mechanistic target of rapamycin#Aging|growth and aging]] has been well established, the relationship between reproduction and aging is still without [[scientific consensus]], and the cellular mechanisms largely undiscovered.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal |authors=Blagosklonny, MV | year = 2010| title = Why the disposable soma theory cannot explain why women live longer and why we age | journal = Aging | volume = 2 | issue = 12 | pages = 884–887 | doi=10.18632/aging.100253}}</ref>
== Background and history ==
British biologist Thomas Kirkwood first proposed the disposable soma theory of aging in a 1977 [[Nature (journal)|''Nature'']] review article.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> The theory was inspired by [[Leslie Orgel|Leslie Orgel's]] [[Error catastrophe|Error Catastrophe Theory of Aging]], which was published fourteen years earlier, in 1963. Orgel believed that the process of aging arose due to mutations acquired during the replication process, and Kirkwood developed the disposable soma theory in order to mediate Orgel's work with [[evolutionary genetics]].<ref name="ReferenceA" />
==Principles== The disposable soma theory of aging acts on the premise that there is a tradeoff in [[resource allocation]] between [[Maintenance of an organism|somatic maintenance]] and [[Parental investment|reproductive investment]]. Too low an investment in self-repair would be evolutionarily unsound, as the organism would likely die before reproductive age. However, too high an investment in self-repair would also be [[Fitness (biology)|evolutionarily unsound]] due to the fact that one's [[Survivorship curve|offspring would likely die before reproductive age]]. Therefore, there is a compromise and resources are partitioned accordingly. However, this compromise is thought to damage somatic repair systems, which can lead to [[DNA damage theory of aging|progressive cellular damage and senescence]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Drenos F, Kirkwood, TB | year = 2005| title = Modelling the disposable soma theory of ageing | journal = Mech Ageing Dev. | volume = 126 | issue = 1 | pages = 99–103| doi=10.1016/j.mad.2004.09.026}}</ref> Repair costs can be categorized into three groups: (1) the costs of increased [[Regeneration (biology)#Tissues|durability of nonrenewable parts]]; (2) the costs of maintenance involving [[Autophagy|cell renewal]], and (3) the costs of intracellular maintenance.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Kirkwood, TB, Rose MR | year = 1991| title = Evolution of senescence: late survival sacrificed for reproduction.| journal = Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci | volume = 332 | issue = 1262 | pages = 15–24| doi=10.1098/rstb.1991.0028}}</ref> In a nutshell, [[Antagonistic pleiotropy hypothesis|aging and decline is essentially a tradeoff]] for increased reproductive robustness in youth.
== Mechanisms == [[File:IGF-1Pathway.png|thumb|The [[IGF-1|IGF-1 pathway]], which represses [[FOXO]], thus preventing [[gene expression]] of longevity-inducing proteins.]]
=== Growth and somatic maintenance === {{main|Mechanistic target of rapamycin#Aging}} Much research has been done on the antagonistic effects of increased growth on lifespan. Specifically, the hormone [[insulin-like growth factor 1]] (IGF-1), binds to a cell receptor, leading to a [[phosphorylation cascade]]. This cascade results in kinases phosphorylating [[FOX proteins|forkhead transcription factor]] (FOXO), deactivating it. Deactivation of FOXO results in an inability to express genes involved in responding to [[oxidative stress |oxidative stress response]], such as [[antioxidants]], [[Chaperone (protein)|chaperones]], and [[heat-shock proteins]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=O'Neill BT, Lee KY, Klaus K, Softic S; et al. | year = 2016 | title = Insulin and IGF-1 receptors regulate FoxO-mediated signaling in muscle proteostasis | journal = J Clin Invest | volume = 126 | issue = 9 | pages = 3433-3346 | doi=10.1172/JCI86522| pmc = 5004956 }}</ref> Additionally, uptake of IGF-1 stimulates the [[Mechanistic target of rapamycin|mTOR]] pathway, which activates protein synthesis (and therefore growth) through upregulation of the translation-promoting [[P70-S6 Kinase 1|S6K1]], and also inhibits [[autophagy]], a process necessary for recycling of damaged cellular products.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Johnson SC, Rabinovitch PS, Kaeberlein M| year = 2013 | title = mTOR is a key modulator of ageing and age-related disease| journal = Nature | volume = 493 | issue = | pages = 338–345 | doi=10.1038/nature11861| bibcode = 2013Natur.493..338J| pmc = 3687363}}</ref> Decline of autophagy causes [[neurodegeneration]], [[protein aggregation]] and [[premature aging]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Komatsu M, Waguri S, Chiba T, Murata S; et al. | year = 2006 | title = Loss of autophagy in the central nervous system causes neurodegeneration in mice | journal = Nature | volume = 441 | issue = | pages = 880–884 | doi=10.1038/nature04723| bibcode = 2006Natur.441..880K }}</ref> Lastly, studies have also indicated that the mTOR pathway also alters [[immune responses]] and stimulates [[cyclin-dependent kinase]] (CDK) inhibitors such as [[p16]] and [[p21]]. This leads to alteration of the [[stem-cell niche]] and results in [[Stem cell theory of aging|stem cell exhaustion]], another theorized mechanism of aging.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Castilho RM1, Squarize CH, Chodosh LA, Williams BO; et al. | year = 2009| title = mTOR mediates Wnt-induced epidermal stem cell exhaustion and aging.| journal = Cell Stem Cell | volume = 5 | issue = 3 | pages = 279–289. | doi=10.1016/j.stem.2009.06.017}}</ref>
=== Reproduction and somatic maintenance=== The mechanism of why reproduction inhibits lifespan with regards to multicellular organisms is still unclear. Although many models do illustrate an inverse relationship, and the theory makes sense from an evolutionary perspective, [[Cell signaling|the cellular mechanisms]] have yet to be explored. However, with regards to [[cellular replication]], the progressive shortening of telomeres is a mechanism which [[Hayflick limit|limits the amount of generations of a single cell may undergo]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Shay JW, Wright WE | year = 2011 | title = Role of telomeres and telomerase in cancer | journal = Semin Cancer Biol. | volume = 21 | issue = 6 | pages = 349–353 | doi=10.1016/j.semcancer.2011.10.001}}</ref> Furthermore, in unicellular organisms like ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'', the formation of [[extrachromosomal rDNA circle]]s (ERCs) in mother cells (but not daughter cells) upon every subsequent division is an identifiable type of DNA damage that is associated with replication. These ERCs accumulate over time and eventually trigger replicative senescence and death of the mother cell.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Kaeberlein M, McVey M, Guarente L | year = 1999 | title = The SIR2/3/4 complex and SIR2 alone promote longevity in Saccharomyces cerevisiae by two different mechanisms| journal = Genes Dev. | volume = 13 | issue = 19| pages = 2570–2580}}</ref>
==Evidence==
===Growth and aging=== There is a large body of evidence indicating the negative effects of growth on longevity across many species. As a general rule, individuals of a smaller size generally live longer than larger individuals of the same species.
==== Animal models ==== In [[Dwarfism|dwarf]] models of [[Mus musculus|mice]], such Snell or Ames mice, mutations have arisen, either rendering them incapable of producing IGF-1 or unable to have adequate receptors for IGF-1 uptake. Furthermore, mice injected with growth hormone have been shown to have progressive weight loss, roughing of the coat, [[Scoliosis|curvature of the spine]], [[Hypertrophy|enlargement of the organs]], kidney lesions and [[Cancer|increased cancer risk]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Bartke A1, Brown-Borg H | year = 2004 | title = Life extension in the dwarf mouse | journal = Curr Top Dev Biol. | volume = 63 | issue = | pages = 189–225| doi=10.1016/j.semcancer.2011.10.001}}</ref> This effect is also seen in different breeds of [[dogs]], where smaller breeds of dogs typically live significantly longer compared to their larger counterparts. Selectively bred for their small size, smaller dog breeds like the [[Chihuahua (dog)|Chihuahua]] (average lifespan of 15–20 years) have the B/B genotype for the IGF-1 [[haplotype]], reducing the amount of IGF-1 produced. Conversely, large dogs like the [[Great Dane]] (average lifespan of 6–8 years) are [[homozygous]] for the IGF-1 I [[allele]], which increases the amount of IGF-1 production.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Sutter NB, Bustamante CD, Chase K, Gray MM | year = 2007| title =A Single IGF1 Allele Is a Major Determinant of Small Size in Dogs| journal = Science | volume = 316 | issue = 5821 | pages = 112–115 | doi=10.1126/science.1137045| bibcode =2007Sci...316..112S}}</ref>
====Human models==== Initially, it was believed that growth hormone actually prolonged lifespan due to a 1990 study that indicated that injection of [[growth hormone]] to men over 60 years of age appeared to reverse various [[biomarkers]] implicated in aging, such as [[Sarcopenia|decreased muscle mass]], bone density, skin thickness, and increased adipose tissue.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Rudman D1, Feller AG, Nagraj HS, Gergans GA; et al. | year = 1990| title =Effects of human growth hormone in men over 60 years old| journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 323 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–6 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199007053230101}}</ref> However, a 1999 study found that administering growth hormone also significantly increased [[mortality rate]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Takala J1, Ruokonen E, Webster NR, Nielsen MS, Zandstra DF, et al. | year = 1999| title = Increased mortality associated with growth hormone treatment in critically ill adults| journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 341 | issue = 11 | pages = 785–792 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199909093411102}}</ref> Recent [[Genome Sequencing|genomic studies]] have confirmed that the genes involved in growth hormone uptake and signaling are largely conserved across a plethora of species, such as yeast, nematodes, fruit flies, mice and humans.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Longo VD, Finch CE.| year = 2003| title =Evolutionary medicine: from dwarf model systems to healthy centenarians?| journal = Science | volume = 299 | issue = 5611 | pages = 1342–1346 | doi=10.1126/science.1077991}}</ref> These studies have also shown that individuals with [[Laron syndrome]], an [[autosomal recessive]] disorder resulting in dwarfism due to defects in growth hormone receptors, have increased lifespan. Additionally, these individuals have much lower [[Incidence (epidemiology)|incidences]] of age-related diseases such as [[type 2 diabetes]] and cancer.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Guevara-Aguirre J, Balasubramanian P, Guevara-Aguirre M, Wei M; et al. | year = 2011| title = Growth hormone receptor deficiency is associated with a major reduction in pro-aging signaling, cancer, and diabetes in humans | journal = Sci. Transl. Med. | volume = 3 | issue = 70 | pages = 70–83 | doi=10.1126/scitranslmed.3001845}}</ref> Lastly, human [[centenarians]] around the world are disproportionately of [[short stature]], and have low levels of IGF-1.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Govindaraju D, Atzmon G, Barzilai N. | year = 2015| title =Genetics, lifestyle and longevity: Lessons from centenarians.| journal = Appl Transl Genom. | volume = 4| issue = | pages = 23–32 | doi=10.1016/j.atg.2015.01.001}}</ref>
===Reproduction and aging=== Numerous studies have found that lifespan is inversely correlated with both the total amount of offspring birthed, as well as the age at which females first gives birth, also known as primiparity.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal |authors=Descamps S, Boutin S, Berteaux D, Gaillard JM.| year = 2006| title =Best squirrels trade a long life for an early reproduction| journal = Proc Biol Sci | volume = 273| issue = 1599 | pages = 2369–2374 | doi= 10.1098/rspb.2006.3588}}</ref> Additionally, it has been found that [[Sexual reproduction|reproduction]] is a costly mechanism that alters the [[Fatty acid metabolism|metabolism of fat]]. [[Lipids]] invested in reproduction would be unable to be allocated to support mechanisms involved in somatic maintenance.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hansen M, Flatt T, Aguilaniu H.| year = 2013| title =Reproduction, fat metabolism, and life span: what is the connection?| journal = Cell Metab.| volume = 17| issue = 1 | pages = 10–19 | doi= 10.1016/j.cmet.2012.12.003}}</ref>
==== Animal models ====
The disposable soma theory has been consistent with the majority of animal models. It was found in numerous animal studies that [[castration]] or [[Genetic disorder|genetic deformities]] of [[Reproductive system|reproduction organs]] was [[correlated]] with increased lifespan.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Drori D, Folman Y.| year = 1976| title =Environmental effects on longevity in the male rat: exercise, mating, castration and restricted feeding| journal = Exp Gerontol.| volume = 11| issue = 1 | pages = 25–32}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authors=Flatt T| year = 2011| title =Survival costs of reproduction in ''Drosophila''.| journal = Exp Gerontol.| volume = 46| issue = 5 | pages = 369–375 | doi= 10.1016/j.exger.2010.10.008}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hsin H, Kenyon C| year = 1999| title =Signals from the reproductive system regulate the lifespan of ''C. elegans''| journal =Nature| volume =399| issue = 6734 | pages = 362–366 | doi= 10.1038/20694| bibcode =1999Natur.399..362H}}</ref> Moreover, in [[red squirrels]], it was found that females with an early primiparity achieved the highest immediate and lifetime reproductive success. However, it was also found that these same individuals had a decreased median and maximum lifespan. Specifically squirrels who mated earlier had a 22.4% rate of mortality until two years of age compared to a 16.5% rate of mortality in late breeders. In addition, these squirrels had an average maximum lifespan of 1035 days compared to an average maximum lifespan of 1245 days for squirrels that bred later.<ref name="ReferenceB" />
In another study, researchers selectively bred [[Drosophila melanogaster|fruit flies]] over three years to develop two different [[strain (biology)|strain]]s, an early-reproducing strain and a late-reproducing strain. The late-reproducing line had a significantly longer lifespan than the early-reproducing line. Even more telling was that when the researchers introduced a mutation in the [[Ovarian|ovarian-associated]] gene ''ovoD1'', resulting in defective [[oogenesis]], the differences in lifespan between the two lines disappeared. The researchers in this case concluded that "aging has evolved primarily because of the damaging effects of reproduction earlier in life".<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Sgrò CM, Partridge L| year = 1999| title = A delayed wave of death from reproduction in Drosophila.| journal =Science| volume =286| issue =5449 | pages = 2521–2524 }}</ref>
Prominent aging researcher [[Steven N. Austad|Steven Austad]] also performed a large-scale [[ecological]] study on the [[coast]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in 1993. Austad isolated two [[opossum]] populations, one from the [[predator]]-infested mainland and one from the predator-absent nearby island of [[Sapelo]]. According to the disposable soma theory, a [[Genetic isolate|genetically isolated]] population subject to low environmentally-induced mortality would evolve delayed reproduction and aging. This is because without the pressure of predation, it would be evolutionarily advantageous to allocate more resources to somatic maintenance than reproduction, as early offspring mortality would be low. As predicted, even after controlling for predation, the isolated population had a longer lifespan, delayed primiparity, and reduced aging biomarkers such as tail [[collagen]] [[Cross linking|cross-linking]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Austad, SN| year = 1993| title =Retarded senescence in an insular population of Virginia opossums (''Didelphis virginiana'')| journal = Journal of Zoology| volume = 229| issue = 4 | pages = 695–708 | doi= 10.1111/j.1469-7998.1993.tb02665.x}}</ref>
====Human models ====
In general, only a few studies exist in human models. It was found that [[Eunuch|castrated men]] live longer than their [[fertile]] counterparts.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hamilton JB, Mestler GE| year = 1969| title =Mortality and survival: comparison of eunuchs with intact men and women in a mentally retarded population)| journal = J. Gerontol.| volume = 24| issue = 4 | pages = 395–411 }}</ref> Further studies found that in British women, primiparity was earliest in women who died early and latest in women who died at the oldest ages. Furthermore, increased number of children birthed was associated with a decreased lifespan.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Westendorp RG, Kirkwood TB| year = 1998| title =Human longevity at the cost of reproductive success |journal = Nature| volume = 396| issue = 6713 | pages = 743–746 | doi= 10.1038/25519}}</ref> A final study found that female centenarians were more likely to have children in later life compared average, especially past the age of 40. The researchers discovered that 19.2% of female centenarians had their first child after the age of 40, compared to 5.5% of the rest of the female population.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Perls TT, Alpert L, Fretts RC| year = 1997| title =Middle-aged mothers live longer |journal = Nature| volume = 389| issue = 6647 | pages = 133 | doi= 10.1038/38148| bibcode = 1997Natur.389..133P}}</ref>
=== Relationship between cell damage and aging=== {{main|Free radical theory}}{{main|DNA damage theory of aging}} [[File:Naked Mole Rat Eating.jpg|thumb|The [[naked mole rat]] has a [[naked mole rat#Longevity|disproportionately long life of 30 years]] through efficient cellular repair mechanisms.]] There are numerous studies that support cellular damage, often due to a lack of somatic maintenance mechanisms, as a primary determinant for aging, and these studies have given rise to the [[free radical theory of aging]] and the [[DNA damage theory of aging]]. One study found that the cells of short-living rodents ''[[in vitro]]'' show much greater [[mutation]] rates and a general lack of genome surveillance compared to human cells and are far more susceptible to [[oxidative stress]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Lorenzini A, Stamato T, Sell C. | year = 2011| title = The disposable soma theory revisited: time as a resource in the theories of aging | journal = Cell Cycle| volume = 10 | issue = 22 | pages = 3853–3856 | doi=10.4161/cc.10.22.18302}}</ref> Other studies have been conducted on the [[naked mole rat]], a rodent species with remarkable longevity (30 years), capable of outliving the [[brown rat]] (3 years) by [[Fold (higher-order function)|ten-fold]]. Additionally, almost no incidence cancer has ever been detected in naked mole rats. Nearly all of the differences found between these two organisms, which are otherwise rather genetically similar, was in somatic maintenance. Naked mole rats were found to have higher levels of [[superoxide dismutase]], a [[reactive oxygen species]] clearing [[antioxidant]]. In addition, naked mole rats had higher levels of [[base excision repair]], DNA damage response signaling, [[Homologous recombination|homologous recombination repair]], [[mismatch repair]], [[nucleotide excision repair]], and [[non-homologous end joining]]. In fact, many of these processes were near or exceeded human levels. Proteins from naked mole rats were also more resistant to [[oxidation]], [[misfolding]], [[ubiquitination]], and had increased [[Translation|translational fidelity]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Azpurua J, Ke Z, Chen IX, Zhang Q, Ermolenko DN; et al. | year = 2013| title = Naked mole-rat has increased translational fidelity compared with the mouse, as well as a unique 28S ribosomal RNA cleavage | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A| volume = 110 | issue = 43 | pages =17350–17355 | doi=10.1073/pnas.1313473110| bibcode =2013PNAS..11017350A}}</ref>
Further studies have been conducted on patients with [[Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome]] (HGPS), a condition that leads to premature aging. Patients with HGPS typically age about seven times faster than average and usually succumb to the disease in their early teens. Patients with HGPS have cellular defects, specifically in the [[Lamin A protein|lamin proteins]], which regulate the organization of the [[Nuclear lamina|lamina]] and [[nuclear envelope]] for [[mitosis]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Pollex RL1, Hegele RA | year = 2004| title = Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome | journal = Clin. Genet.| volume = 66| issue = 5 | pages =375–381 | doi=10.1111/j.1399-0004.2004.00315.x}}</ref>
Lastly, as mentioned previously, it has been found that the suppression of autophagy is associated with reduced lifespan, while stimulation is associated with extended lifespan. Activated in times of [[caloric restriction]], autophagy is a process that prevents cellular damage through clearance and [[recycling]] of damaged proteins and [[organelles]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Glick D1, Barth S, Macleod KF. | year = 2010| title = Autophagy: cellular and molecular mechanisms| journal = J. Pathol. | volume = 221 | issue = 1 | pages =3–12| doi=10.1002/path.2697}}</ref>
== Criticism== One of the main weaknesses of the disposable soma theory is that it does not postulate any specific cellular mechanisms to which an organism shifts energy to somatic repair over reproduction. Instead, it only offers an [[Evolution|evolutionary perspective]] on why aging may occur due to reproduction. Therefore, parts of it are rather limited outside of the field of [[evolutionary biology]].<ref name="ReferenceC" />
===Caloric restriction=== {{main|Calorie restriction#Sirtuin-mediated mechanism}} [[File:Soma Disposable.png|thumb|Schematic showing the reallocation of energy investment towards [[DNA repair|self-repair]] during [[caloric restriction]].]] Critics have pointed out the supposed [[Inconsistency|inconsistencies]] of the disposable soma theory due to the observed effects of caloric restriction, which is correlated with increased lifespan.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Blagosklonny, MV| year = 2010| title = Solving puzzles of aging: From disposable soma to signal-transduction pathways| journal = Russ J Gen Chem. | volume = 80 | issue = | pages =1407}}</ref> Although it activates autophagy, according to classical disposable soma principles, with less [[Caloric|caloric intake]], there would less total energy to be distributed towards somatic maintenance, and decreased lifespan would be observed (or at least the positive autophagic effects would be balanced out). However, Kirkwood, alongside his collaborator Darryl P. Shanley, assert that caloric restriction triggers an adaptive mechanism which causes the organism to shift a higher proportion of resources to somatic maintenance, away from reproduction.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Shanley DP, Kirkwood TB.| year = 2000| title = Calorie restriction and aging: a life-history analysis.| journal = Evolution | volume = 54 | issue =3 | pages =1407}}</ref> This theory is supported by multiple studies, which show that caloric restriction typically results in [[Sterility (physiology)|impaired fertility]], but leave an otherwise healthy organism.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Holliday R.| year = 2000| title = Food, reproduction and longevity: is the extended lifespan of calorie-restricted animals an evolutionary adaptation?| journal = BioEssays | volume = 10 | issue =4 | pages =125–127|doi=10.1002/bies.950100408}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authors=Masoro EJ, Austad SN.| year = 1996| title = The evolution of the antiaging action of dietary restriction: a hypothesis.| journal = J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci | volume = 51 | issue =6 | pages =387–391}}</ref> Evolutionarily, an organism would want to delay reproduction to when resources were more plentiful. During a resource-barren period, it would evolutionarily unwise to invest resources in progeny that would be unlikely to survive in [[famine]]. Mechanistically, the [[Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide|NAD]]-dependent [[Deacetylate|deacetylase]] [[Sirtuin 1]] (SIRT-1) is upregulated during low-nutrient periods. SIRT-1 increases [[insulin sensitivity]], decreases the amount of [[inflammatory cytokine]]s, stimulates autophagy, and activates FOXO, the aforementioned protein involved in activating stress response genes. SIRT-1 is also found to result in decreased fertility.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Cantó C, Auwerx J.| year = 2009| title = Caloric restriction, SIRT1 and longevity.| journal =Trends Endocrinol Metab| volume = 20 | issue =7 | pages =325–331|doi=10.1016/j.tem.2009.03.008}}</ref>
In additional to differential [[wikt:partitioning|partitioning]] of energy allocation during caloric restriction, less caloric intake would result in less metabolic waste in the forms of [[free radicals]] like [[hydrogen peroxide]], [[superoxide]] and [[hydroxyl radicals]], which damage important cellular components, particularly [[mitochondria]]. Elevated levels of free radicals in mice has been correlated with neurodegeneration, [[Myocardial|myocardial injury]], [[Anemia|severe anemia]], and premature death.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Pérez VI, Bokov A, Van Remmen H, Mele J; et al.| year = 2009| title = Is the oxidative stress theory of aging dead?| journal =Biochim Biophys Acta| volume = 1790 | issue =10 | pages =1005–1014|doi=10.1016/j.bbagen.2009.06.003}}</ref>
===The Grandmother hypothesis=== {{main|Menopause#Evolutionary rationale}} Another primary criticism of the disposable soma theory is that it fails to account for why women tend to live longer than their male counterparts.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Ginter E, Simko V | year = 2013| title = Women live longer than men| journal = Bratisl Lek Listy. | volume = 114 | issue = 2 | pages =45–49}}</ref> Afterall, females invest significantly more resources into reproduction and according to the classical disposable soma principles, this would compromise energy diverted to somatic maintenance. However, this can be reconciled with the [[grandmother hypothesis]]. The Grandmother Hypothesis states that [[menopause]] comes about into older women in order to restrict the time of reproduction as a protective mechanism. This would allow women to live longer and increase the amount of care they could provide to their [[grandchildren]], increasing their evolutionary fitness.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hawkes K | year = 2003| title = Grandmothers and the evolution of human longevity| journal = Am. J. Hum. Biol.| volume =15 | issue =3 | pages =380–400| doi= 10.1002/ajhb.10156}}</ref> And so, although women do invest a greater proportion of resources into reproduction during their [[Age and female fertility|fertile years]], their overall reproductive period is significantly shorter than men, who are able of reproduction during and even beyond [[middle age]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Vinicius L, Mace R, Migliano A| year = 2014| title = Variation in Male Reproductive Longevity across Traditional Societies| journal = PLoS One| volume =9 | issue =11 | pages =e112236| doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0112236| bibcode =2014PLoSO...9k2236V}}</ref> Additionally, males invest more resources into growth, and have significantly higher levels of IGF-1 compared to females, which is correlated with decreased lifespan. Other variables such as increased [[Testosterone|testosterone levels]] in males are not accounted for. Increased testosterone is often associated with reckless behaviour, which may lead to a high accidental death rate.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Celec P, Ostatníková D, Hodosy J. | year = 2015| title = On the effects of testosterone on brain behavioral functions| journal = Front. Neurosci.| volume =9 | issue = | pages =12| doi=10.3389/fnins.2015.00012}}</ref>
=== Contradicting models === A few [[Contradiction|contradicting]] animal models weaken the validity of the disposable soma theory. This includes studies done on the aforementioned naked mole rats. In these studies, it was found that reproductive naked mole rats actually show significantly increased lifespans compared to non-reproductive individuals, which contradicts the principles of diposable soma. However, although these naked mole rats are [[mammalian]], they are highly [[atypical]] in terms of aging studies and may not serve as the best model for humans. For example, naked mole rats have a disproportionately high longevity quotient and live in [[Eusociality|eusocial societies]], where breeding is usually designated to a [[Eusociality#In mammals|queen]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Dammann P, Burda H | year = 2006| title =Sexual activity and reproduction delay ageing in a mammal.| journal = Curr. Biol.| volume = 16 | issue = 4 | pages = 117–118 | doi=10.1016/j.cub.2006.02.012}}</ref>
=== Sex biases and environment === The disposable soma theory is tested disproportionately on female organisms for the relationship between reproduction and aging, as [[Parental investment#Females as the more investing sex|females carry a greater burden in reproduction]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hammers M, Richardson DS, Burke T, Komdeur J. | year = 2013| title = The impact of reproductive investment and early-life environmental conditions on senescence: support for the disposable soma hypothesis.| journal = J Evol Biol | volume = 26| issue = 9 | pages = 1999–2007| doi=10.1111/jeb.12204}}</ref> Additionally, for the relationship between growth and aging, studies are disproportionately conducted on males, to minimize the [[Estrogen|hormonal fluctuations]] that occur with [[Menstrual cycle|menstrual cycling]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Wu JJ, Liu J, Chen EB, Wang JJ; et al. | year = 2013| title = Increased mammalian lifespan and a segmental and tissue-specific slowing of aging after genetic reduction of mTOR expression| journal = Cell Rep. | volume = 4| issue = 5 | pages = 913–920| doi=10.1016/j.celrep.2013.07.030}}</ref> Lastly, [[aging#Biological basis|genetic]] and [[Gene–environment interaction|environmental factors]], rather than reproductive patterns, may explain the variations in human lifespan. For example, studies have shown that [[Poverty|poorer individuals]], to whom nutritious food and [[medical care]] is less accessible, typically have higher birth rates and earlier primiparity.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Murray, S. | year = 2006| title = Poverty and health| journal = CMAJ | volume = 174| issue = 7 | pages = 923| doi=10.1503/cmaj.060235}}</ref>

'''Djwal Khul''' (variously spelled 'Djwhal Khul', 'Djwal Kul', the 'Master D.K.', 'D.K.', or simply 'DK'), is believed by some [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|Theosophists]] and others to be a [[Tibet]]an disciple in the tradition of ancient [[esoteric]] spirituality known as The Ageless Wisdom tradition. The texts describe him as a member of the '[[Spiritual Hierarchy]]', or 'Brotherhood', of [[Mahatma]]s, one of the [[Masters of the Ancient Wisdom]], defined as the spiritual guides of mankind and teachers ancient [[cosmological]], [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]], and esoteric principles that form the origin of all the world's great philosophies, mythologies and spiritual traditions.<ref name="neff">{{cite book|last= Neff |first=Mary K. |title= Brothers of Madame Blavatsky |pages= 31, 46–47|year=2003 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |isbn= 0766157822}}</ref> According to Theosophical writings, Djwal Khul is said to work on furthering the spiritual evolution of our planet through the teachings offered in the 24 books by [[Alice Bailey]] of Esoteric Teachings published by The Lucis Trust; he is said to have telepathically transmitted the teachings to Bailey and is thus regarded by her followers as the [[communications director]] of the Masters of the Ancient Wisdom.
==In Theosophy and the writings of Alice Bailey== {{Theosophy}}
Djwal Khul's name first appeared in the work of [[Madame Blavatsky]], a co-founder of the [[Theosophical Society]] and author of "[[The Secret Doctrine]]", published in 1888, which was primarily written by Koot Hoomi and Morya, according to Blavatsky and others in the Mahatma letters.<ref>The Writing of The Secret Doctrine - By Kirby Van Mater - www.theosociety.org/pasadena/invit-sd/invsd-4.htm</ref><ref>Letters from the Masters of the Wisdom, No. 19, 1:47, 5th ed.</ref>
Bailey writes in August 1934, in the first person voice of DK: [I am] "a Tibetan disciple of a certain degree, and this tells you but little, for all are disciples from the humblest aspirant up to and beyond The Christ Himself. I live in a physical body like other men on the borders of Tibet and at times (from the exoteric standpoint) preside over a large group of Tibetan Lamas, when my other duties permit."<ref name="bailey">{{cite book|last= Bailey |first= Alice. A |title= Discipleship in The New Age vol.1|pages= vii|year=1944|publisher=Lucis Trust }}</ref> In some writings, his name was omitted and he was referred to by the abbreviation "Master D. K." or the appellation "The Tibetan".<ref name="neff"/><ref name="guenon">{{cite book|last= Guenon |first= Rene |translator=Alvin Moore, Jr. |translator2=Cecil Bethell|title= Theosophy: History of a Pseudo-Religion|pages= 41–42|year=2004 |publisher=Sophia Perennis |isbn= 0900588802}}</ref><ref>Mackay, Alex, ''The History of Tibet.'' Routledge University Press, 2003, p. 714</ref><ref>Bailey, Alice A. ''Esoteric Healing,'' Lucis Trust. 1951. p 714</ref>
In 1919 [[Alice Bailey]] (1880–1949), severed her links with the Theosophical Society for various reasons and later began writing books she described as being [[telepathy|telepathically]] dictated to her by Djwhal Khul whom she referred to as "The Tibetan"<ref>Bailey, Alice A. ''The Unfinished Autobiography''. Lucis Trust. 1951. pp 162-163</ref> (later associated with the initials ''D.K.''). According to Bailey, her D.K. was the main author behind Blavatsky's "The Secret Doctrine".<ref>Bailey, Alice A. ''Initiation Human and Solar,'' Lucis Trust., p. 58</ref><ref>Bailey, Alice A. ''Esoteric Healing'', Lucis Trust., p. 521, 536, og 565</ref><ref>Bailey, Alice A. ''The Rays and Initiations,'' Lucis Trust., p. 255</ref><ref>Bailey, Alice A. ''The Externalisation of the Hierarchy,'' Lucis Trust., p. 685</ref> Bailey stated that after initial resistance, she was eventually persuaded by the quality of what she had written in 'dictation' in the first few weeks work with DK to continue to write down the communications from this source. She wrote for 30 years, from 1919 to 1949.<ref>Bailey, Alice A. ''The Unfinished Autobiography''. Lucis Trust. 1951. From the Preface by Foster Bailey, p 1</ref>
Bailey wrote that Djwal Khul's intention was the revelation of [[esoteric]] teachings that were valuable for the continued training and teaching of spiritual aspirants in the 20th and early 21st century. She believed her work was done on behalf of the "spiritual hierarchy" of advanced beings, that included Djwal Khul, whose sole interest was to guide humanity towards the establishing of goodwill and right human relations, the vital first steps that would help prepare the way for the "Reappearance of the [[Maitreya (Theosophy)|Christ]]" (called by Theosophists ''The [[Maitreya (Theosophy)|Maitreya]]''). Alice Bailey's 24 books with DK were to be the second in a series of three revelations, after Blavatsky's "The Secret Doctrine", that were meant present the preparatory teachings that would serve to usher in the [[New Age]] referred to as the ''[[Age of Aquarius]]'', because the astrological sign of Aquarius will soon succeed this present Piscean cycle in the cycle of the [[astrological age]]s.
In a preface included in many of Bailey's books, Djwal Khul, in the dictations described by Bailey, refers to the fact that he has been reported to be an abbot of a Tibetan monastery and the spiritual preceptor of a large group of [[lama]]s. She wrote that he lived in Northern India, near the borders of [[Tibet]]. Other than that the books do not include personal details about Djwal Khul and the dictated content focuses on his [[esoteric]] teachings. Of the minimal personal details, Bailey writes that Djwhal Khul considers himself a disciple of a certain degree in the spiritual, non-physical, [[ashram]] of the Master [[Koot Hoomi]], who is considered by Theosophists and other students of Alice Bailey's books to be another member of the same "spiritual hierarchy" of advanced beings.
[[C. W. Leadbeater]] claimed that he saw Djwal Khul [[Teleportation in theology|teleport]] into a room in which he and Madame Blavatsky were sitting.<ref>Leadbeater, C.W. ''The Masters and the Path'' Adyar, Madras, India: 1925 Theosophical Publishing House Pages 8-9</ref>
==In other New Age movements==
Bailey's work and her books with Djwal Khul were published by the [[Lucis Trust]], an organization she set up with her husband, [[Foster Bailey]]. Over time, Djwal Khul's name has appeared in the writings about [[Ascended Master]]s (a phrase not used or sanctioned by either The Tibetan or Mrs. Bailey) of various [[New Age]] organizations (of debatable credibility according to some{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}) such as the ''[[Ascended Master Teachings]]'' of [[Elizabeth Clare Prophet]], who claims that she has channeled Djwal Khul as well as the other Mahatmas, such as ''[[Koot Hoomi]]'' and ''the Master El [[Morya (Theosophy)|Morya]]'', among many others, resulting in dozens of volumes of transcriptions.<ref>{{cite book|last= Klimo |first= Jon|author2=Charles Tart |title= Channeling: Investigations on Receiving Information from Paranormal Sources|year= 1998 |publisher=North Atlantic Books |isbn= 1556432488 |page= 54}}</ref> The leaders of these groups described themselves as having direct contact with him and other "Masters of Wisdom", and to be working as their disciples on the physical plane. Within the Arcane School founded by Bailey, DK's works are studied along with other spiritual teachings of all ages. He is treated as a teacher and neither he nor his books have become objects of devotion.
==Previous incarnation==
According to [[Elizabeth Clare Prophet]], one of Djwal Khul's previous incarnations was as Caspar, one of the [[Three Wise Men]] (the one who gave gold to [[Jesus]]).<ref>Prophet, Mark L. and Elizabeth Clare ''Lords of the Seven Rays'' Livingston, Montana, U.S.A.:1986 - Summit University Press - Page 33</ref>
==Function in the spiritual hierarchy==
It is believed by the followers of [[Benjamin Creme]] and the followers of the [[Alice Bailey]] teachings, that Djwal Khul coordinates the activities of the seven masters of the [[Seven Rays]] to advance the ''Plan of the Masters'' and functions as the [[communications director]] of the Ascended Masters since he is believed to have telepathically transmitted the teachings in the Alice A. Bailey material to Alice Bailey.
==Criticism==
The teachings of Djwal Khul, as conveyed through Bailey's many books in his name, contain and deal with many controversial topics, stating that there are widespread evils ingrained in popular ideas and statements about [[nationalism]], [[race relations]], [[American isolationism]], [[Soviet Union|Soviet totalitarianism]], [[fascism]], [[Nazism]], and [[Zionism]]. The books include content critical of the then current 19th century and early 20th century ideas and views about people of [[Ethnic groups of Africa|African]] descent, [[Aboriginal Australians]], the [[Jewish people]] and [[Arabs]], and of [[Judaism]] and orthodox [[Christianity]] and fundamentalist movements of both East and West. <ref name="penn1">{{cite book | last = Penn | first =Lee | title =False Dawn: The United Religions Initiative, Globalism, and the Quest for a One World Religion | publisher = Sophia Perennis | year = 2004 | pages = 267–268, 273, 299 | isbn = 159731000X}}</ref> <ref name="miller1">{{cite book | last = Miller | first = Elliott | title =A Crash Course on the New Age Movement: Describing and Evaluating a Growing Movement | publisher = Baker Book House | year = 1989 | isbn = 0801062489 | page = 197}}</ref> <ref name=Shnirelman>[http://sicsa.huji.ac.il/13shnir.html Shnirelman, Victor A. ''Russian Neo-pagan Myths and Antisemitism''] in ''Acta no. 13, Analysis of Current Trends in Antisemitism.'' The Vidal Sassoon International Center for the Study of Antisemitism at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. 1998. Retrieved 2007-08-22</ref>
==Skeptical view==
The scholar [[K. Paul Johnson]] maintains that the "Masters" that [[Madame Blavatsky]] wrote about and produced letters from were actually idealizations of people who were her [[mentor]]s. Johnson asserts that the Djwal Khul was actually Dayal Singh Majithia, a member of the ''Singh Saba'', an [[Indian independence movement]] organization and [[Sikh]] reform movement.<ref>Johnson, Paul K. Initiates of Theosophical Masters Albany, New York:1995 State University of New York Press Page 49</ref>
Also see the article “Talking to the Dead and Other Amusements” by Paul Zweig ''New York Times'' October 5, 1980, which maintains that Madame Blavatsky's revelations were fraudulent.

In [[philosophy]], '''downward causation''' is a [[causal relationship]] from higher levels of a system to lower-level parts of that system: for example, mental events acting to cause physical events,<ref name=Galaaen2006>{{cite web|url=https://www.duo.uio.no/bitstream/handle/10852/24951/the_disturbing_matter.pdf?sequence=1|title=The Disturbing Matter of Downward Causation: A Study of the Exclusion Argument and its Causal-Explanatory Presuppositions|author=Øistein Schmidt Galaaen|date=2006|accessdate=2014-09-26}}</ref> The term was originally coined in 1974 by the philosopher and social scientist [[Donald T. Campbell]].<ref name=Galaaen2006/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pespmc1.vub.ac.be/DOWNCAUS.html|title=Downward Causation|publisher=Principia Cybernetica|accessdate=2013-06-07}}</ref>
== Theories == [[File:Practopoietic cycle of causation.gif|thumb|Practopoietic cycle of causation]]According to [[practopoiesis|practopoietic]] theory of system organization,<ref>Nikolić, Danko. [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S002251931500106X "Practopoiesis: Or how life fosters a mind."] Journal of Theoretical Biology 373 (2015): 40-61.</ref> downward causation in biological systems always involves the environment. Downward causation does not occur by direct causal effects from higher to lower levels of system organisation. Instead, downward causation occurs indirectly because the mechanisms at higher levels of organisation fail to accomplish the tasks dictated by the lower levels of organisation. As a result, inputs from the environment signal to the mechanisms at lower levels of organisation that something is wrong and therefore, to act. For example, a species may find itself under evolutionary pressure to adjust to novel circumstances—which is a form of downward pressure for adjustment. Similarly, an organism may be under downward pressure to express different genes if the expression patterns from the past did not lead to desired results. Another special case of downward causation is [[supervised learning]] (of neuronal networks) in which both behavior and environment governs the propagation from higher to lower levels.
This leads to a unique form of a causal interaction pattern—called a ''practopoietic loop (cycle) of causation''. The end result is that the mechanisms responsible for mental events cause physical events only based on their joint interaction with the environment.
An interesting consequence is that neither behavior of an organism nor its mental operations can be considered fully or exclusively [[supervenience|supervenient]] on the body of the organism. On the one hand, behavior is not supervenient on all parts of the body. On the other hand, due to the necessary interactions with the environment at all levels of organization, behavior is supervenient also on some aspects of the environment. The same holds for the mental operations, or the [[mind]].
